quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I really think that we're just starting into this golden era of what it might mean to be a writer on the internet.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: Sets a forward-looking mental model that the creator economy is entering a new phase worth building for.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The economic model for supporting great writing on the internet has been generally pretty terrible for the entirety of the internet's history.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A contrarian diagnosis that reframes the core problem as monetization, not distribution or content quality.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: in the last year or so, even in the last few months, I think there's been so many really interesting success stories now from writers who might not even consider themselves writers.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable opportunity: broaden your target user beyond traditional “writers” to anyone with valuable expertise.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: People who are able to make a living, maybe even make a fortune just doing great work and not needing to have millions and millions of viewers or play the attention games of other networks, but just do really high quality work and have a relatively small number of people value it highly enough to pay for it.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A memorable subscription-based model: focus on high-value work for a small paying audience rather than chasing mass attention.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Retool and Stytch
quotes.text: Retool allows teams as small as just one person to build a suite of custom internal apps in a fraction of the time that you think it takes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical leverage point: small teams can rapidly ship internal tooling without the usual time/cost assumptions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Retool and Stytch
quotes.text: The productivity gains of custom apps is now within reach, not just for large enterprises but for small teams as well.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A reframing that democratizes internal tooling—suggesting ROI from custom apps isn’t limited to big-company scale.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Retool and Stytch
quotes.text: Snowflake saves about 26 hours a week of manual spreadsheet work with custom internal apps built on Retool.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark for quantifying internal-tooling impact in time saved per week.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Retool and Stytch
quotes.text: Stytch customers have been able to increase conversion by over 60% after spending just one day integrating.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific outcome metric tying authentication/onboarding improvements directly to conversion gains with minimal integration time.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Retool and Stytch
quotes.text: Your engineers will come and thank you for using Stytch, because Stytch keeps you from having to build authentication in house and the integration process is super fast and super smooth.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable build-vs-buy guidance: outsource auth to save engineering time and reduce implementation friction.

quotes.topic_title: Sachin’s path from Cocoon to Substack
quotes.text: We just kept running into the wall that you run into when ultimately advertising is the business model that is powering this whole thing, and what that means is you need to accumulate a lot of time spent and attention and convert that into basically sellable eyeballs.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A clear articulation of how an ad-driven business model constrains product decisions toward maximizing attention rather than user value.

quotes.topic_title: Sachin’s path from Cocoon to Substack
quotes.text: But it's not that hard to imagine what a better solution would be. It's just that ads as the business model made it really hard to pull that off.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that product quality is often limited less by ideas and more by incentives created by the monetization model.

quotes.topic_title: Sachin’s path from Cocoon to Substack
quotes.text: We always looked up to Substack as a really good example of basically that same principle, which is if you imagine rewiring the internet around paid subscriptions, direct subscriptions between, in Substack's case, readers and writers, what could that unlock and could it unlock a clearly better user experience?
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A memorable mental model—“rewiring the internet around paid subscriptions”—for designing products around direct value exchange instead of ads.

quotes.topic_title: Sachin’s path from Cocoon to Substack
quotes.text: Cocoon was in a lot of ways like a journey to explore what that might look like for this one particular use case of just helping you feel close to a handful of people.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A concrete example of narrowing scope to a specific human need (“feel close”) and small audience (“a handful of people”) to explore a better experience.

quotes.topic_title: Substack product org structure and evolution
quotes.text: I think we're coming to the close of this kind of one-time inflection point of becoming a product driven company and having a product process and structure and PMs and full stack product teams.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: Captures a concrete scaling milestone: shifting from founder/engineering-led building to a product-driven org with repeatable process and full-stack teams.

quotes.topic_title: Substack product org structure and evolution
quotes.text: We have four product managers in addition to myself, and we have three essentially kind of full stack product teams now that have a PM and an engineering manager, a data person or a designer, engineers and things are starting to roll.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: Gives a specific, replicable team composition model for early-stage product orgs (PM+EM+data/design+engineers).

quotes.topic_title: Substack product org structure and evolution
quotes.text: Part of why I think it's remained pretty consistent is exactly what you mentioned, which is the teams aren't oriented around product surfaces.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: Offers an org-design principle: orient teams around enduring problems rather than UI/surface areas to reduce churn and reorgs.

quotes.topic_title: Substack product org structure and evolution
quotes.text: We have teams that are oriented around customers and solving bit of a timeless customer problem. We'll never be done serving writers.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for durable team charters—anchor on a “timeless customer problem” that won’t get “completed.”

quotes.topic_title: Substack product org structure and evolution
quotes.text: Growth is never a problem that you check the box off on.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A counter to “finish growth then move on”: treat growth as a continuous capability, not a one-time project.

quotes.topic_title: Working with a product-strong founder
quotes.text: I think the first thing was really treating my role in the beginning more as a facilitator than a decision maker when it comes to product.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A practical stance for PM leaders working with product-strong founders: prioritize alignment and enablement before trying to own decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Working with a product-strong founder
quotes.text: When I first joined, I felt like my main role was actually just solving that. And if nothing else, if Chris could have a really good sense of what all the teams are doing and if the teams knew where he was coming from and could start to get better at modeling him and his vision, that would be a win.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: Defines an actionable early mandate: close the “founder context gap” by improving visibility both ways and helping teams internalize the founder’s vision.

quotes.topic_title: Working with a product-strong founder
quotes.text: We start the week, Chris and I, we sit down for an hour. We go through what do we feel like are the big problems to focus on this week, what are the things we're worried about. We sit down at the end of the week and we check in again.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A concrete operating cadence for maintaining alignment and trust with a founder through structured weekly bookends.

quotes.topic_title: Working with a product-strong founder
quotes.text: To go back to your question, I think a thing that I really try to be mindful of right now is, how do I catch up?
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A counterintuitive mental model: the PM’s job is often to “catch up” to a founder’s multi-year thinking rather than immediately redirect it.

quotes.topic_title: Working with a product-strong founder
quotes.text: Chris has been thinking about this problem for five times as long as I have. If I can get a good sense of where his vision starts from and catch up those few years and help the teams do the same, that'll go a long way.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A transferable heuristic for founder-led companies: explicitly account for the founder’s time advantage and systematically help the org absorb it.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling pains and who thrives in hypergrowth
quotes.text: is almost by definition any time you figure out how to do a thing, you'll now reach this next phase of growth and it'll be obsolete.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A practical mental model for hypergrowth: process “solutions” expire quickly, so teams must expect continual reinvention.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling pains and who thrives in hypergrowth
quotes.text: The main thing I care about is are we just getting better every week, every month, certainly every year.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: Shifts the goal from finding perfect processes to building a cadence of continuous improvement.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling pains and who thrives in hypergrowth
quotes.text: Doing the thing well means that you're not going to know what you're doing.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that reframes uncertainty as a sign of effective execution in high-growth environments.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling pains and who thrives in hypergrowth
quotes.text: I think there's almost like a personality type that has to be okay with being humbled all the time and feeling like you don't know what you're doing.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: Highlights a key hiring/fit criterion for scaling teams: comfort with ambiguity and frequent resets.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling pains and who thrives in hypergrowth
quotes.text: The advice is just do the best thing you can think of right now. Don't assume this will last anyway, and that's good enough.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for practitioners: optimize for the next iteration rather than over-engineering a “final” process.

quotes.topic_title: Facebook vs Substack: prioritization and trade-offs
quotes.text: Facebook may be the most extreme example of trying to solve so many different problems for so many different people in one tiny rectangle basically, that a big part of the product manager's job in a situation like that is going to be managing trade-offs.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for big-company PM work: the core job is managing permanent trade-offs across constrained surfaces and audiences.

quotes.topic_title: Facebook vs Substack: prioritization and trade-offs
quotes.text: In Facebook's case, sometimes it's, "Oh, if we do this, we just can't do this. It's going to be bad for this other thing. If we put a watch tab at the bottom, will that mean that people don't get a marketplace tab? What does that mean for this whole org and what the product is?"
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A concrete example of prioritization as mutually exclusive, org-wide trade-offs rather than simple sequencing.

quotes.topic_title: Facebook vs Substack: prioritization and trade-offs
quotes.text: By doing A, it might mean B is harder to do forever. Whereas at a startup, a lot of it is time. Time is the main variable. We can do this now and that means that we can't do this other thing until later.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A practical framework for prioritization: big companies face irreversible constraints; startups mostly face time/sequence constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Facebook vs Substack: prioritization and trade-offs
quotes.text: There is a bit of an order of operations at play here where doing something right now might unlock our ability to do something later.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A sequencing heuristic for formative products: prioritize work that unlocks future capabilities rather than just immediate impact.

quotes.topic_title: Principles and north star: control for writers/readers
quotes.text: It starts with an opinion for how the internet should work, where people should be in control over their destiny to a much greater extent than has ever really been the case over at least the last 10, 15 years, where all of a sudden, everyone just started spending all of their time in a handful of these public squares that were powered by ads.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A clear product philosophy/north star that anchors prioritization in user agency rather than ad-driven incentives.

quotes.topic_title: Principles and north star: control for writers/readers
quotes.text: I think where that leads you down from a prioritization standpoint is often starting from, okay, if we could do something in a bunch of different ways, is there a way that provides more control to the writer or more control over the experience that the reader has to them? Is there a way that provides much less control? All things equal, do the one that holds constant this principle of control.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: An actionable decision rule for choosing between product options: default to the path that maximizes creator/reader control.

quotes.topic_title: Principles and north star: control for writers/readers
quotes.text: I think that's a good example where there's certainly a way to do that where writers have the max amount of control. We picked that way even if it might seem harder to pull off.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A counterintuitive prioritization stance: choose the harder implementation if it preserves the core principle of user control.

quotes.topic_title: Principles and north star: control for writers/readers
quotes.text: Once someone subscribes to my newsletter, they see these 10 as, "Hey, you should check these out. I think these are awesome."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of a recommendations mechanic that keeps curation in the hands of writers rather than an algorithmic feed.

quotes.topic_title: Recommendations feature: origin, skepticism, and impact
quotes.text: The way it came to be was that we noticed this organic behavior emerging, which was that a lot of readers of Substacks were starting to discover Substacks, but the way that was happening was typically through the lens of that original writer.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A product discovery pattern: observe organic user behavior first, then formalize it into a feature anchored on an existing trust relationship.

quotes.topic_title: Recommendations feature: origin, skepticism, and impact
quotes.text: But then going back to that principle of like, okay, well, if we were to do that, let's say we were to insert it at the bottom of our post or in an email or something, it's clearly a thing now where the writer who owns that space is not really in control over what the experiences that they're offering their readers.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A clear product principle tradeoff: algorithmic recommendations can violate creator control over their audience experience.

quotes.topic_title: Recommendations feature: origin, skepticism, and impact
quotes.text: What if we just ask writers, who do you recommend? What if we just put that in the subscribe flow and just made it as simple as possible?
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: Actionable methodology: replace “you might like” algorithms with explicit, creator-curated recommendations placed at the highest-intent moment (subscribe).

quotes.topic_title: Recommendations feature: origin, skepticism, and impact
quotes.text: There was this virality at play now where when you recommend a bunch of people, those people will get an email that say, "Hey, Lenny's recommending you and here's all the readers that he's sending you." It created this goodwill viral loop, which was really interesting to see play out.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A viral loop design: notify beneficiaries with attribution + impact to trigger reciprocity and more sharing.

quotes.topic_title: Recommendations feature: origin, skepticism, and impact
quotes.text: Recommendations specifically now have driven in the millions of new subscriptions for writers across the board, across I think like tens of thousands of unique writers that have received subscriptions from the recommendations feature.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: Concrete impact metric showing the scale of network-driven growth from a non-algorithmic recommendation system.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Vanta
quotes.text: SOC 2 can either open the door for bigger and better deals, or it can put your business on hold. If you don't have a SOC 2, there's a good chance you won't even get a seat at the table.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear framing of SOC 2 as a gating factor for enterprise sales and deal velocity.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Vanta
quotes.text: Beginning a SOC 2 report can be a huge burden, especially for startups. It's time consuming, tedious, and expensive.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights the operational reality and cost profile teams should plan for when pursuing compliance.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Vanta
quotes.text: Over 3,000 fast growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete adoption and efficiency data point that quantifies potential leverage from automation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Vanta
quotes.text: It's like a really good growth hack on Substack right now to try to get a lot of subscribers to recommend you.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable growth tactic: systematically drive recommendations to accelerate newsletter subscriber acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Vanta
quotes.text: My system right now is I want to share the wealth as much as I can, so I rotate through different newsletters.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A simple operational system for managing inbound recommendation requests while spreading exposure across creators.

quotes.topic_title: Product rollout approach: pilots and Product Lab
quotes.text: One of the principles I guess in this playbook that we're trying to write is we call it build with writers, build with readers.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A clear product-development principle that formalizes co-building with core user groups as a default operating model.

quotes.topic_title: Product rollout approach: pilots and Product Lab
quotes.text: One way to do it would be to almost as a strong default, anytime we're going to make a fundamental change to how Substack works, do it in a way where we bring writers along.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: Actionable rollout guidance: treat involving users early as the default for major changes rather than an exception.

quotes.topic_title: Product rollout approach: pilots and Product Lab
quotes.text: Instead, we just ran a little pilot.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A simple but high-leverage methodology shift: validate via pilots before committing to broad launches.

quotes.topic_title: Product rollout approach: pilots and Product Lab
quotes.text: This is just an invite only little group of a hundred or so writers that we know are interested in being on the bleeding edge of what Substack is becoming.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A concrete example of creating a structured, opt-in cohort to accelerate iteration and reduce rollout risk.

quotes.topic_title: Product rollout approach: pilots and Product Lab
quotes.text: Often the thing that we end up shipping on day one tends to be pretty different from what we had in mind before we went through this process.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: Counterintuitive lesson: real user feedback loops can materially change the initial solution, so plan for iteration rather than certainty.

quotes.topic_title: Handling press cycles and staying focused
quotes.text: The whole thing here is just parsing out the signal from the noise.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A simple decision-making framework for handling press cycles: explicitly separate what matters from what’s just distraction.

quotes.topic_title: Handling press cycles and staying focused
quotes.text: There's very little chatter in the blogosphere media sphere that would actually impact our day-to-day when I think about it.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A counterweight to overreacting to media narratives—most coverage doesn’t change execution priorities.

quotes.topic_title: Handling press cycles and staying focused
quotes.text: But I'd say 90% of the chatter about Substack is going to probably ultimately just be a distraction to our product team at the end of the day that should just be focused on executing on the vision.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A concrete heuristic (“90%”) for how aggressively teams should discount press chatter and stay focused on shipping.

quotes.topic_title: Handling press cycles and staying focused
quotes.text: You just learn to just keep your heads down and keep shipping. Ultimately, that's all that matters.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: Actionable operating principle for teams under scrutiny: prioritize consistent delivery over reacting to external noise.

quotes.topic_title: Substack’s future: writer tools, community, reader apps
quotes.text: People who are able to make a living, maybe even make a fortune just doing great work and not needing to have millions and millions of viewers or play the attention games of other networks, but just do really high quality work and have a relatively small number of people value it highly enough to pay for it.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A counterintuitive monetization model: focus on high-value work for a smaller paying audience rather than chasing massive reach.

quotes.topic_title: Substack’s future: writer tools, community, reader apps
quotes.text: When I see the next one to two years play out for the writer side of the equation, a lot of what we're going to try to do is just make it much simpler to get started, to have your Substack.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A clear product roadmap insight: reducing setup friction is a primary lever for creator growth.

quotes.topic_title: Substack’s future: writer tools, community, reader apps
quotes.text: If you have an audience anywhere, Substack's never going to be the place where have the biggest audience probably, but it certainly should be the place where your most valuable audience comes home to, where they get your best work.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A positioning framework for creators: treat Substack as a “home base” for your highest-value fans, not a top-of-funnel growth channel.

quotes.topic_title: Substack’s future: writer tools, community, reader apps
quotes.text: We're seeing a lot of really interesting success stories now of people that might have a big Instagram following or YouTube following and certainly Twitter following were able to use Substack now as this home base, this place to try to accumulate their most valuable audience that they own in the sense that they get their email address, they can export them at any time, and just build really simple tools to just help them deliver their best work.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A practical playbook: convert followers on other platforms into an owned, portable audience via email capture and exportability.

quotes.topic_title: Substack’s future: writer tools, community, reader apps
quotes.text: We kind of see Substack evolving not as some new type of social media, but true alternative to how you might spend that most valuable slice of your time.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A memorable strategic lens: compete for users’ “most valuable slice” of attention by offering a controlled, reader-first experience.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for new writers: start and iterate
quotes.text: My first piece of advice would be to just start it and see what happens. Start it. Have a way to start gathering subscribers. Put a link to it somewhere. Write one or two things.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A simple, actionable launch playbook: publish immediately and set up basic subscriber capture before overthinking format or strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for new writers: start and iterate
quotes.text: If you're not much of a writer, try posting a video, recording some audio, turn into a little podcast. Just start basically and see what happens and see what kind of interest there might be out there for what you have to say, especially if you already have a following on other platforms as well.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: Encourages iterating on format (video/audio/text) to lower the barrier to publishing and validate demand quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for new writers: start and iterate
quotes.text: I think that there's a real risk that if your entire following is locked into one platform where you don't have a ton of control over, your ability to reach those people deterministically and certainly to monetize that in some way, it seems like it's a tenuous place to be in the current age of the internet.
quotes.speaker: Sachin Monga
quotes.context: A platform-risk mental model: owning a direct subscriber relationship reduces dependency on algorithms and improves reach and monetization control.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for new writers: start and iterate
quotes.text: But I will say that is exactly what I did and that's exactly how I got to what I do now. I had zero intention of ever doing this. Charging for writing that I'm writing, that's crazy.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example that validates the “just start” approach and highlights how monetization can emerge after experimentation.
